Good enough to be rated 8.

Japanese name: BOKURA WA MINNA KAWAISOU
English name: THE KAWAI COMPLEX GUIDE TO MANORS AND HOSTEL BEHAVIOR
SPOILERS FREE REVIEW 
This anime has no particular deep plot like most comedy types, just a High School boy Kazunari Usa and his wish to live a normal independent high school life (like that ever goes well in a school genre) and there's a Senpai he wants to impress as well. 
One thing that literally shines bright in this anime is the AMAZING ANIMATION, I haven't seen many animes but I'd say that the animation style itself goes hand-in-hand with the flow of the anime, looks colorful, detailed, cheerful andoverall GREAT. Keep in mind this is an anime from 2014.

The simplest of expressions have so much details in them. The character design are also well made. 

The music played along with the romantic and comedy scenes are very much in sync and adds more impact to the scenes themselves. 


Ok, word of advice this anime looks cute and all but damn does it throw some unexpected heavy mature comedy. Though the comedy itself is genuine with little to no generic same-old stuff that you'll burst out laughing unexpectedly. This is a very nicely done rom-com with hilarious romantic scenes to heart warming comedy (wait, I got that backwards, ah well...) 


One of the things after the animation in this anime that I loved was the uniqueness of the characters and how well they were mixed together. And given a good amount of screen time to give each one enough time to shine so that the viewers get to know more about them. 

We have the pervert masochist, the drunk office lady with literally no luck with men, the sadistic college girl... (yeah, I did mention unique didn't I?) The loving old manager lady and the shy book loving Senpai. 


After getting to know his fellow tenants Usa decides to go find another place (I mean who wouldn't... They crazy) as he's leaving he runs into the Senpai and, lo and behold she's already living there (guess ya know what he decided next)


Anyways, imo this is an anime where "notice me Senpai" is done right in a very cheerful and hilarious way.


I'd recommend this if you're looking for a GOOD HAPPY watch because from the animation to the dialogs it's one BIG HAPPY ride. 


GENRE: Comedy, Romance, School, Seinen, Slice of Life.


RATINGS: I'd give it 8.6/10

Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou, or the The Kawai Complex Guide to Manors and Hostel Behavior, is a very recent addition to the slice of life genre.  While there were problems with it on the distribution side, (Because for some reason, it took days for the damn show to be subbed!), this show was a show that was very worth its time.
Story (7.34/10):  The story of Bokura, as I call it, revolves around the life of Kazunari Usa, a new first year student who begins his life as a first year in high school, away from his parents, at a nearby boarding house.It is there that he finds that the girl that he likes at school, named Kawai Ritsu, is one of his roommates at this boarding house, prompting him to begin his journey of high school romance, one step at a time.


Now, we've all at one point or another have seen this sort of story in various kinds of slice of life's.  A new person stepping into a new world that he must now try and adapt to.  (Working!, Chuunibyou, Dog Days, etc.)  What makes this story different from any other, is really nothing when you get down to the concrete part of the show.  As a base idea, Bokura doesn't differ much from a good chunk of other shows.  So what makes this show better/unique?  Well, it's their comedy and tone of the show.


Bokura wa Minna does a very good job at giving off a very, very, very relaxed tone to the show.  Nothing really feels serious in the grand scheme of things, and for the most part, the show really just shows the characters having a good time, and enjoying life as much as they can.  It's this relaxed tone that makes the show so good-feeling to watch, and overall, a very good experience.  


The comedy of the show is also quite excelling too.  The show itself is quite heavily character-based, and shows that with the colorful characters that it has.  The show never takes itself too seriously and tosses in jokes and other forms of sarcasm, comedic desperation, and other forms of moments in which some are actually quite memorable and provide a good laugh.  


There are however, some downfalls.  Depending on what kind of story you want, this can be seen as a good or a bad point.  The show has a strange cohesion feel to it.  Some things and plot points carry from episode to episode, while others are random and appear for only one episode.  In short, the show has a mix of one-shot episodes that focus purely on one thing, and are resolved later, and others are plot points that span from one episode to the next, to the next.  While personally, I never minded the fact that some episodes were smack dab in the middle of something new, it is something I felt like bringing up.


Another thing about the story that made it a bit meh, is its end.  To put it bluntly, the show is incomplete.  The way it ends feels like that something new has begun rather than resolved.  While the main focus of the show has taken a step forward, it didn't feel like a real ending, leading me to believe that there will be a second season, in which I am not sure of.


Overview:

+  Great comedy

+  Wonderfully calm and pleasant tone

+  Simple idea

-   Some cohesion issues between episodes

-   Incomplete ending


Characters (8.79/10):  For any character driven anime, the characters of course, are very important.  They have to have a very memorable personality, quirks, and design for people to remember.  While the characters in this show didn't fill in that last category, the first two are certainly filled to the brim.


Up first is Kazunari Usa, our main protagonist.  From the beginning to the end, Usa is shown to be basically your average boring protagonist of being kind to everyone, having 1.5x the amount of common sense than everyone else in the cast, and just generally being, well, normal.  Not that there's anything wrong with his character, since his quest for love is admirable given his obstacles, but compared to the other characters, he's the least memorable of the bunch.  (He is still quite memorable nonetheless, as we do get a decent amount of backstory on why he is the way he is.)


Kawai Ritsu, or Ricchan as everyone in the series calls her, (except Usa, who says Senpai all of the time), the main female protagonist of the series.  From her debut, it is apparent that she is a fan of reading.  Well, that's an understatement.  For essentially 75-80% of the screen time she gets, she is holding a book, either reading it, hugging it to her chest, or picking them out to read.  To put it bluntly, she loves books like Keima from TWGOK loves visual novels.  Over the course of the series, we, the audience get to know more about her character and see her grow as a person altogether as she tries to step out of the shell that she has confined herself in.  You learn a good deal about her, making her character all the more developed and interesting.


Next is Shirosako, or Shiro, as he is known in the series.  This guy is a masochist, and if you've ever seen MM, then that is essentially what you're going to see.  This guy is literally the only other guy in the series next to Usa that you will care about, since his character is actually quite interesting.  Outside of his masochistic nature, (which essentially makes up for every joke he tells more or less), he is shown to be a rather helpful and caring guy, helping out everyone as much as he can and has some pretty good ideas on occasion.  


Next is Nishikino Mayumi.  Ah, Mayumi.  She is basically the desperate 20 something year old, that has big boobs.  Her personality is quite interesting, seeing how most of the time she acts like a teenager than a grown woman, attempting to pry into Usa's love life and trying to make him seem like a pervert rather than anything else.  While I'm not a huge fan of desperate females in animes, (quote Becki from Nourin.  *shudder*), I find her quite an interesting character as on occasion, she does help to add to the plot while adding her own spin of comedy into the grand scheme of things.


Next is Watanabe Sayaka.  This girl is terrifying.  While her introduction to the series is a bit late in comparison to everyone else, she definitely makes a lasting impression as being a bit of a sadist.  She in conniving, very luring, and overall, basically teases everyone on who and what they are (mostly Mayumi.)  That's essentially what she does the entire series, and she plays that comedic part very well.  


And finally, the owner of the Kawai complex, Kawai Sumiko.  This woman is quite an interesting character.  While for the most part, she acts very laid-back and calm, she, has a dark and terrifying side that has many times, terrified the residents of the boarding house.  And also at times, she will do whatever she can to get things she wants, such as making Usa take a job in exchange for tickets to something.  


Apart from these 6, whom I see as being the main characters, we have a whole slew of other oddball characters.  Some of which, are quite memorable in the series, while others sort of just fade away.  What I like about this series is the fact that the overall cast isn't so large that you would forget one person or another.  It really focuses on the people it does have and makes them as good as they possibly can be.


On their own, these characters sound quite bland; nothing really seems too exciting.  But, when you put them all together, the result, is magical.  This series really puts emphasis on its characters by making them talk and interact with each other in many different ways.  It is because of these interactions that the plot is enjoyable to watch, it is the reason that this series has great comedy, and is the reason why the show is so light-hearted and good.  


Overview:

+  Memorable cast

+  Very good character interactions

+  Decent sized cast with some emphasis on everyone


Art and Sound (9.32/10 and 7.49/10):  The art in this show is just staggeringly amazing.  Every single scene of its normal animation look quite stunning and just so good. 


There are two forms of art in this anime.  One is the standard animation, and the other is a comedic chibi animation.  Like I have said before, the normal animation of the show is just breathtakingly beautiful.  Everything from the characters to the backgrounds looks stunning.  If you don't believe me, just watch the five minutes of the first episode, and you'll see what I mean.  (The last time I saw something this good was in Nagi no Asukara.)  


Aside from that, the show has a very simple chibi animation in heavy contrast to the actual show's animation itself.  For starters, there is little to no detail in the characters in the chibi animation whereas there is heavy detail in the designs of the characters in the normal animation.  While I don't find any problems with the show intertwining its animation styles by putting both of the animations in the same scene, sometimes, the transitions from one style to another happen rather sudden and sometimes awkward.  But for the most part, I'd doubt anyone would really care.  


In terms of music, I find the opening and ending tracks to be relatively memorable.  The opening is a very instrument heavy piece that gives off the show's casual and calm feel to it.  Personally, I sat through the whole of the opening, as I enjoyed it very much.  On the flipside, we have the ending, which to me, I also found enjoyable, but not as memorable.  Sure, the tone of it sounded cute, quirky, and relatively nice sounding, but I didn't feel as obligated to listen to it as I did with the opening.  The tracks in the show itself were mostly just background tracks, so nothing really stood out.


Overview:

+  FANTASTIC ART

+  Good comedic chibi art

+  Good opening and ending

-   Some awkward art style transitions

-   forgettable background tracks


Personal Enjoyment (8.45/10):  I love a good slice of life.  Whenever I want to watch something that isn't too serious in its plot, I watch a slice of life.  This show definitely proved itself as a good choice.  Aside from the distribution problem where I had to sometimes wait five or so days for the english subtitles release, this show was a very good experience to watch.  It never had a serious tone with itself and made itself known to have probably the lightest tone that I have seen in anime in a long time.  It was just good, classic fun that showed that you're never too old to have fun.  If you want to watch a good slice of life with a very minute romantic subplot, this is a good show to watch.  Personally, I enjoyed it a lot.


Overall Score: (8.31/10)

As the end of the year draws closer, I've found myself in a position where I want to get caught up on the year's more popular titles as soon as possible. Unfortunately, that also means watching shows of very similar genres back-to-back. It's not that I end up getting sick of the genre, but moreso that the faults with each series become more glaring than they normally would if I hadn't watched something from that genre in the while, and the most frequent genre suffering from this is the romantic comedy. So, did my mostrecent viewing manage to make itself stand out from the crowd that's begging to make it into my lineup?


          Once again, I find myself in the position of having to judge a show primarily on its comedy, a process that's rarely ever less than 100% opinionated. As for Kawai Complex, I did end up laughing quite a bit throughout the series. From rampant sensual fantasies to hard-hitting slapstick, this series employs a wide variety of humor. Unfortunately, it ended up settling into a comfort zone about halfway throughout, and I actually ended up being able to predict what was going to happen. Here's the bit where Shiro wants to be abused. Here's the bit where Mayumi blows her top. Here's the bit where Sayaka acts like a horrible person. Predictability is the number one killer of comedies, and I found myself laughing less and less as the series progressed.


          Fortunately, the series isn't entirely a comedy, and there's a lot of character-motivated story lines that get fleshed out quite a bit. While Usa does turn out to be a fairly typical "I have a crush on the main love interest but I'm nervous about trying to get close to her" character, he still ends up being really smart about it, and it's hard to not end up really liking him when his mistakes are those that we have to deal with in the real world all the time. Am I forcing myself on the girl I like? Am I being too nice to this group of people? How can I improve my relationship with this person? He definitely felt like he was close to transcending "character" and turning into someone that felt very real.


          Ritsu also felt like much more than a standard character type, and she was easily the most interesting character in the series. Her standout feature was that she loves to read and gets intensely engrossed in whatever book she's reading, so much so that she won't even notice when someone else is talking to her. While loving books feels like an acceptable excuse for this character to exist, she ends up going well beyond that, and we slowly get to see the extremely fleshed-out introverted nature of someone who gets exhausted from trying to keep pace in social situations. As for a blossoming romance with Usa, the progression is rather slow, but the signs of it are definitely there, and following this progression make marathoning this series infinitely more enjoyable, though I will say that there were a few points where the writing really felt like it was trying to force this relationship to happen when it didn't need to do so. The slow build was there, but there were definitely points where it felt like it was rushing to get somewhere that it didn't need to get to any time soon.


          As for other characters, they ended up not getting as much fleshing out as I would have liked. Shiro is a masochist who's a lot nicer than he seems, Mayumi is a slightly older woman struggling with love, Sayaka is the mean-spirited two-face, and all of them only get one episode each all to themselves. Plus, as I mentioned earlier, a lot of their comedic cards end up getting played far too often, sometimes to the point where I didn't even want them on-screen because I knew they would ruin any romantic tension that was building between Usa and Ritsu.


          The animation was produced by Brain's Base (D-Frag!, My Little Monster), and this series definitely lives up to the reputation that this studio has been building over the years. Set designs were always a touch more elaborate than average to bring each environment to life, character designs were significantly more refined than the standard fair but still maintained some level of moe-ness, and Ritsu is seriously one of the cutest-looking characters I've seen this year in practically everything she does, a quality I found extremely important when showing a scene from Usa's perspective. There were also a ton of different oddities in the animation used for comedic or cinematic effect, from shrinking an entire frame into the center of the screen to bizarre lighting effects and character design morphs. Additionally, while I normally don't draw attention to this, I do want to point out that the opening animation is actually a bit awe-inspiring, as it seems to provide a glimpse into Ritsu's world of literature and her immersion in it.


          There is currently no dub for this series, but if one were to be produced, it would most likely be done by Seraphim Digital. However, on the subject of original Japanese casts, both this series and Nagi no Asukara have convinced me that I need to start keeping track of how many times Kana Hanazawa (Ritsu) shows up in something that I'm watching. I believe Kawai Complex brings me up to 25 roles that I've heard her play now, and I'm certainly not getting sick of her any time soon.


          The soundtrack was composed by Akito Matsuda (Baka and Test; Love, Chuunibyou, & Other Delusions), and he ends up doing what he normally does: wacky and crazy tracks for comedic moments and softer piano melodies for the more emotional scenes, though nothing in particular really stood out. The opening theme "Itsuka no, Ikutsuka no Kimi to no Sekai" was performed by fhána and opens with an upbeat pop track, while the ending theme "My Sweet Shelter" was performed by the lead female voice cast and play us out with a bouncing pop tune guaranteed to get stuck in your head.


          Ultimately, while Kawai Complex certainly was one of the better comedies I've seen this year and the romance felt very natural for the most part, a comedy that ends up being incredibly predictable by the time it reaches the second half isn't something I can recommend actually purchasing.

If for you, an enjoyable anime needs characters and humor above all else, this will be one of your all time favorites. This is the type of anime where they get you attached to every character for every single character trait for what they're worth. 
-Plot
There's not much of a plot to follow, so if you're into adventure and action anime as a top genre, you may feel a little left out on this one.  (6) 
-Art
The art is quite surreal but still the classic anime style we all know and love. It flips between realistic-ish and cartoon-ish similarly to Sora no Otoshimono, butnot quite as frequently (9)\n\n
-Sound\n
The music gives nice support and the sound effects (which aren't a common use) work nicely. (8)\n\n
-Characters\n
Everyone is emotionally, physically, personality-wise different in some way. All of the characters are lovable, even if you hate them at first. It's like getting a desk change in school and sitting next to someone you don't know but you think you already dislike them but end up good frieids. (note, in the end of the latest episode at this time (episode 7) they give a hinting toward a new bunch of characters)  (10)\n\n
Overall this is the type of anime I absolutely love. Everything about it just works for me.\n
If you've seen Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo, it's very similar to this anime in the way it is, except in Sakurasou all of the cast has some sort of talent in a way or another.\n
If you like animes with great character development, this is meant for you.

When you’ve been watching anime for a certain amount of time, things might start to look the same, in not so kind words, you just feel like you’re watching the same thing over and over. In those occasions, if you honestly feel like that, you’d better just drop the damn thing and be done with it.
Why start with such statement? Simple, because a series like The Kawai Complex Guide to Manors and Hostel Behavior feels like one of those… and at the same time it doesn’t.
Several washed out stereotypes can be expected, and maybe most of them may be applied in this case… so whydid the series stood out for me? The answer is simple: I bought the premises in it. 


This deserves and explanation… here it is.


Even if we can’t see beyond the first impression, and the oh so rehashed characteristics, there’s always something else to be found by the ones who desire to do so, in this case is the ever so important relationship between Kawai and Usa, to be precise, is how we see the relationship itself. We can doubt Usa’s motives to build a relationship with Kawai, and fall into the classic archetypes of anime relationships, this being the romantic soapy kind, or the most sexualized ecchi kind (both portrayed in the series by standardized scenes), and leave it at that, if we choose this judgment the series falls short on being anything else, but if it catches us in that sweet moment where anything might just for a moment seem special, I promise you you’re in for a sweet ride… that’s me being clichéd.


The point is that there’s nothing really new in this anime kind relationship, but at the same time there’s a tiny space where we are allowed to believe in the honesty of its premise. It’s ironic because the series itself is happy with not giving anything new, you have all the classic weird comedy moments were outspoken linear characters do and react the way you expect them to, the defying moments where the hero most prove the strength of his already established resolve, and of course those awkward romantic moments were, In the classic anime way, the characters bond in a way that seems credible only for them in that moment. Any one of the mentioned situations can be easily found in similar works, but there’s something about the way they are portrayed this time that makes them so much credible and relatable.


I can’t really say anything, or give any particular examples of scenes that gave me this unique vibe, without spoiling the damn thing, in the end you have to test it for yourself. At least, trust me in this, it won’t take long for any seasoned anime spectator to either hate the series or love it, in that sense, if said experience exists, it is a constant that keeps da feels going for all the duration of the series.


Maybe it was just me, in said moment, that just saw in the drawings and in the weird colors used on the series something else. Say put your own expectations in a fictional work, and maybe in this occasion it’s me the one that’s being selfish in the interpretation, maybe unfair with the creators, I don’t know, but isn’t that the point? Taking the content for yourself? Believing in the honesty of such apparently repeated “feelings”?


I really don’t know, what I do know is that The Kawai Complex Guide to Manors and Hostel Behavior got me believing in the honesty of closeness beyond the weight of all the social stereotypes, and in the possibility of seeing human relationships beyond the norms in spite of said norms weight… and most importantly, beyond all the weight of anime clichés.


For those brief chapters I was a believer.

I have just finished watching the 5th episode in the series and I gotta say my sides are hurting from laughter and my cheeks are sore from smiling!
Even if the events are a little cliche its such a fantastically well thought out story line that is simple and full of heart warming moments. All the encounters with the two main characters are enough to satisfy your hunger for romance but won't give you too much to stop watching. And the supporting characters add to the comedy to make it an all round winner.
I love the amazing artwork with the added touch of beautiful colours andshining surfaces here and there. I also love the chibi-like narrations when the main characters are discussing or imagining something in their heads. I also love that when characters are enjoying something you'll see an aura of flowers or if they are depressed a great big purple aura around them. It makes communicating feelings of not so eccentric characters a lot easier and often adds to the comedy.


The characters fit into the common stereotypes found in anime and act accordingly, which again adds to the humor, and as the story progresses you cant help but fall in love with each and every one.


The beautiful OP by fhana fits perfectly and every time I watch an episode I can't help but listen to the whole thing. The sound during the episodes isn't annoying like some animes and fits so perfectly that you barely notice it. 


All up, I highly recommend this anime to anyone who wants a refreshing change and love slice of life, romance with a side dish of comedy animes!!

I laughed, a lot. I found this anime to be something special, a little different from what I've seen before and hopefully I can find something similar. Here is why.
Story 8/10:  The story is about Usa Kazunari, a highschool boy starting to live on his own because of his parents transfering jobs. He moves in to the Kawai Complex, where he finds very strange induviduals. The story revolves around how Usa and the others act together. The story main goal in my opinion is to make the viewers laugh, even so the story has some romance. Thankfully the romance is very simple and easyto go around if you're not a real romance fan.


Art 9/10: I liked the art very much, not enough for a perfect 10 but very close. It's very colorful and playful. I first found the art to be quite strange but after a few episodes I found myself to like it a lot. The main pro is how colorful it is. The only con to the art in my opinion are the eyes, they're slightly to colorful and pops out a littlebit much. But as a whole it's very good.


Sounds 9/10: I enjoyed the sound. It is very simple and fits the anime well. The sounds of the anime doesn't make it a 9 but I enjoyed both the Opening and Ending to give it a 9.


Character 9/10: I loved some of the characters, hated a few. The development might not be at it's best but I found the two main characters very good and that's what brought up this score. But to be fair, as this is mainly focused of comedy, the characters beside the two main ones are mostly comic reliefs. The main characters counts the most in my opinion.


Enjoyment 10/10: A PERFECT 10. I enjoyed this very very much. I laughed so many times. It was very easy to watch and easy to understand. It's everything you would want out of a slice of life comedy. Simple and not any scenes to fill out the time.


Overall 9/10: Overall I would say that it's a 9. Mostly because story is not perfect. Even so this is a anime to watch, no matter who you are or what you like you should try it. Happytime all the 12 episodes, mostly comedy with a hint of romance. GO WATCH IT!

Aw...This was the first anime I ever watched... It was adorable and every second of it was ughhhh the character development was amazing... This is on my favourite romance anime's and I have re-watched it recently! I would definately recommend it to someone who's watching anime for the first time as it isn't as gorey as some animes are ( Corpse Party I'm talking to you -3-) I watched this alone as my first one and at first I found all the subtitles confusing as I was a beginners ( But not now !! I've gone my children (0W0)//) I wish I'd discovered the worldof anime sooner :3 But, Overall a beautiful characters and story!!!! 030

Notice me senpai: the animation is a more fitting title to this anime.
To be honest after I finished this anime I just think of it as another typical romcom anime, some scenes were pretty cute but some were just plain stupid and the story didn't leave any emotional impact to me. The animation and music is good tho and I also liked the comedy part but the romance is a little bit lacking. Nothing is really unique in this anime but overall I do enjoyed it.
Also it didn't have a conclusive ending since it didn't cover the whole manga, but honestly I'm not interested enoughto continue reading the manga.

Alright, Bokura Wa Minna Kawai-sou...
one of my favourite anime of all time.
Story: Solid 8, I really enjoyed the story anyone can relate to it at some point. The main character loves the main introverted girl who likes to read books all the time and she's honestly the cutest thing ever, with this story we will obviously see some character development which takes us to the next thing.
Character: Amazing a definite 9. Now as I explained the main plot and the whole love situation which creates a whole new level of character development the support characters are actually incredibly funny and cool you will really enjoywatching them teasing the main guy who loves the girl, and she literally doesn't give any damn about him it's hilarious.


Art: I can't really say much about the Art It Is OUTSTANDING The anime is visually pleasing I LOVE IT.


Sound: Another 10, It is pretty amazing good sound amazing voice acting linked with the characters faces and facial expressions, amazing art style.


Enjoyment: I Loved The anime, I watched it 11 times now <3.


Overall: A Solid 9, Cute anime, fun to watch, fun to rate.


Enjoy<3.

Bokura wa minna kawaiso is a pun -- it means "we're all from Kawai Boarding House", but it also means "we are all pathetic".  Unfortunately, I felt that was absolutely true about most of the characters in this anime.
I didn't find much to like here.  Slice of life doesn't usually have much of a plot, which isn't a problem for me per se, if instead it gives subtle insights into the lives of the particular people whose "slice" we get to see, or into life in general.  We didn't get any of that here.
Story: The miniscule plot of Kazunari Usa trying toget senpai Kawai Ritsu to notice him turned out to be mostly painful and after a while boring.  Much time is spent on the antics of the various "weirdos" of the Kawai Boarding House, but they're not interesting weirdos, they're one trick ponies who're overacted to extremes.  Supposedly this is a romance, but actually it's a one-sided crush (which I have no doubt is parlayed into a romance in the manga, just because Usa is persistent, and the Japanese seem to think stalkery behaviour like his proves "love").  But in the anime?  No romance. Unless you consider it romantic to exchange phone numbers and email addresses.  The comedy is execrable; crude seinen humour; nothing original here at all.  I don't think I laughed even once.  I smiled a few times, mostly at Ritsu and Usa; the rest was all nearly unbearable noise.


Art: The best thing about the show.  Pretty, detailed art with nice colours, and the animation isn't bad either.


Sound:  Inoffensive.  Peppy OP and ED.  Nothing special.  Voice talent is always hard to notice when most of them overact for humourous effect.  I had no favourites here, Hanazawa Kana is kind of bland because Ritsu is so reserved; she only really shines a couple of times.


Character:  Kazunari Usa is bland, nice to a fault, and basically a clueless git; your typical insert character.  He crushes hard on Kawai Ritsu from the very first moment he sees her at the school library.  Ritsu is an introverted bookworm, but Usa is so clueless that it takes him 5 episodes to come up with the bright idea of asking her something about books, and even then he doesn't do it very intelligently.  


Then we have the "weirdos":  Shirosaki, a peeping tom and masochist who cherishes being beaten up which is fortunate since the two young women are violent; Nishikino "here come my boobs" Mayumi who has men on the brain and completely fails to sort the losers from the good guys; and college girl Watanabe Ayaka, who is a complete bitch to everyone.  Add Kawai Sumiko, the elderly manager who dispenses the occasional bit of trite wisdom with her pudding.


I liked only Ritsu.  Hey, I am an introverted bookworm, what's not to like -- I'd be friends with her in no time. Here's a hint to the lovelorn:  take an interest in what your crush is interested in, get to actually know them instead of idolizing your image of them.  You don't have to do the same things as they, but show that you care.  Usa is too dim for that, though by the end of it he starts to catch on, and at least he seems genuine about it instead of just using it as a tool.  I don't dislike him so much as I feel he is a blank piece of paper with not much personality of his own.


Enjoyment:  poor.  Were it not for the art and sound, this anime would be below average for me.

So I finally watched it after seeing multiple recommendations for it almost every I turn and honestly.. It was ok? It wasn't the best for a 'romance' genre and definitely wasn't what I had hope for.. SPOILERS AHEAD
Story 6/10: So the story isn't terrible, it's actually quite enjoyable.. but then we get to the some parts where it becomes a total snooze fest and I don't understand why it was added in.. The anime could of easily became a 24 episode series where it showed the development between the two main characters but at last it did not and I'm not expecting a season 2considering the time gap between the first and second! The story good though and really fit in well with it showing Ritsu coming out of her shell from this lonely book worm to a.. lonely book worm who can actually socialize abit more now... Overall the story is a sweet and innocent series and will do wonders if you're looking for that type of series. The romance in it isn't strong and it will go no where considering it ended at this point.. It's really slow paced and is kind of stupid.. It took the MC 12 god damn episodes just to get her phone number!! 12 EPISODES!!! Talk about slow.. Personally I don't mind if it's slow IF there is a ending where they get together. The ending was sweet and it showed how they developed over the course of the series but I just didn't enjoy the ending as much as it could of gone.. You could say it completely ruined it for me to see this end the way it did..


Art 7/10: The art/animation is actually pretty decent in this considering it was released just under 4 years ago.. It's got lots of colors and liked to pop out at you and you'll definitely know what's happening just from the animation.. Sad moments are amazing because you can actually feel the power behind it and really get into it! The animation was dope!


Sound 7/10: I'm not big for sound but nothing really seemed out of place and it did have some good soundtracks here and there..


Character 7/10: Personally hated how slow the pace and considering there were no end results for the two main characters but that's nothing that can be helped... The characters were decent and I enjoyed watching a different type of anime where it shows them coming out of their shells, I kind of got a Sakurasou no pet na kanojo vibe for this anime and I'm sure anyone who watched it will too.. Each character developed surprisingly well and it was good to see them develop as a whole! It would of been nice to see more backstory to each character and become more involved with them showing their childhood/past and how it actually came to how they are now.. 


Overall: It isn't the bed anime for a romance kind of person or is looking for a sappy love story where they end up together.. But if you're looking for a slow paced romance story which will go no where because the anime ended so quickly then here you go.. I still enjoyed it to a certain point and would recommend it if you've come off of a action packed anime with a lot of death and are looking for something sweet and innocent looking but that's pretty much it's only use for you..

If you live in an apartment complex, you may be forced to interact with the other people who live there. That is okay; you may end up becoming friends with them. In fact, if you get lucky, the one you love may be living in that apartment complex.... or depending on the situation, you may be unlucky. Anyway, this anime was one of the anime I planned to watch back in Spring 2014 but unfortunately missed out on until now. Now, after watching all 12 episodes, I regret not watching it before; it's just that good.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is my review of Bokura waMinna Kawaisou, known in English as The Kawai Complex Guide to Manors and Hostel Behavior.


Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou is set in a boarding house called the Kawai Complex, run by an elderly woman named Sumiko. The protagonist of this anime, Kazunari Usa, moves to the Kawai Complex due to his parents travelling overseas for work. In the library of his school, he falls in love with a girl who's reading a book, and it turns out that this girl, Ritsu Kawai, also lives at the Kawai Complex. He also meets the other residents of the Kawai Complex, such as Shiro (a masochist who is actually his roommate), Mayumi (a woman who has zero luck with men), and Sayaka (a college student who loves toying with men). Life goes on in the Kawai Complex, as Usa interacts with these people as well as trying to get closer to Ritsu.


One thing I should say about this anime is that it has BEAUTIFUL animation. Brains Base did a solid job with the animation, and the character designs are also solid. The opening ("Itsuka no, Ikutsuka no Kimi to no Sekai" by fhána) and ending themes ("My Sweet Shelter" by Kana Hanazawa, Rina Satou, and Hisako Kanemoto) are quite catchy, and I like listening to them. Neither of them are the best songs I've ever listened to, but they fit the tone of this anime very well. The voice acting is also very good, especially Kana Hanazawa as Ritsu; she really nailed her role!


The story in this anime.... admit it, you guys; it's been used before. I'm not saying that it's a bad story; it's just cliche, with an unsatisfying conclusion that could make anyone who really liked this anime think, "OH MY GOD, WHERE'S SEASON TWO OF THIS?!" Believe me, those are my thoughts right now.


Anyway, this anime has a variety of characters who are quite likable. I think the character I liked the most was Ritsu. It's not because she is the love interest here; it's because I completely relate to her. I'd personally rather read books than interact with other people. I also really liked Usa; it's obvious that he really cares about Ritsu, and I rooted for him the whole way through. The supporting cast is also a very interesting one, especially Shiro. His masochistic behavior made for a lot of funny moments.


Overall, I really enjoyed Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou. If you're in the mood for a nice, relaxing rom-com, this one is right up your alley. It would be quite fun to see what goes on in the Kawai Complex!

Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou is a feel good, light romance story, and while it remains easy to enjoy, it is ultimately let down by poor pacing in character development. The male lead is a stereotypical shy guy starting his first year of high school, who wishes for peace and quiet in his life, and an intelligent demure girl to spend his time with. He quickly discovers the target of his desires, a quiet bookish girl who attends his school and lives in the same apartment building. Let the wooing begin. 
But, all sorts of barriers lay between our hero and heroine, which make up thebulk of the story. They both have to get over their awkward natures and shyness, as well as their tenancies to assume the feelings and intentions of others. They are also beset by a horde of meddling supporting characters, who mainly just get in the way and provide comedic relief. 


Slowly, the two get closer to each other, and when I say slowly, I mean really slowly. The core of these sorts of shows though is sexual tension. Will they understand each other? Will this person's actions be misinterpreted? It's hyperbole, but at some point I kind of felt like it was Inuyasha, 150 episodes in and he still hadn't sealed the deal with Kagome. So, maybe people like to watch the struggle? Maybe a bit of projection going on? Anyway, this tension is the one thing the show has going for it. It's also it's greatest weakness because the characters can't really evolve out of their initial states without destroying or at least lessening that tension, so slow to no character development.


Nothing special on the art or music front. If you're prepared for a cute, awkward ride, give Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou a try.

_Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou_ was, in all, enjoyable. It was not particularly exceptional, nor was it original, but for a casual series to relax to, it was certainly a nice bit of entertainment. The comedic aspects were well done, if a little overblown, while the main character's romantic plot and character development made for a decently well-developed and perhaps above-average "serious" side to the series.
The story is fairly typical: you have a high schooler, a boarding house setting, a potential love interest, a cast of seemingly stereotypical characters that tend to antagonise the main character but aren't specifically malicious (or... are they?). The main charactertries to get closer to the love interest, only to dig himself and get himself into various kinds of trouble with the boarding house residents.


Where the story did quite well goes hand-in-hand with the characterisation: the story between the main character, KAZUNARI Usa, and KAWAI Ritsu. Ritsu is a bookworm and a bit of a loner, preferring to keep to herself than interact with the rest of the boarding house members. For this kind of anime, you'd expect Usa to figure out the big secret to her heart or something deep in her past, get through to her, they share a kiss or overt intimate moment of some other sort, curtains, applause, show's done. But the writers obviously put some greater thought in developing this story: their relationship evolves with time and familiarity and not without effort, and their individual characters evolve quite naturally along with that, which left me mostly quite satisfied with the overall course of that story. It is wrapped up in a sense, it's not a 'happily ever after': it is, indeed, left quite open-ended.


I did say I was satisfied with the _overall_ course of the story. Many of Usa's and Ritsu's actions, and their characterisation in its finer details, left something to be desired. They often acted in ways that went beyond my suspension of disbelief for their characterisation, seeming far too exaggerated for the sake of comedy (or worse, when intended as an earnest reaction). A potent example of this is how Usa thought about Ritsu and around her, which felt disproportionate even for a high school boy of his character. This is perhaps reflected on all the other characters: in fact, while a certain depth of character and backstory was revealed for some characters (Chinatsu, Hayashi and Shiro come to mind), they mostly stuck to their stereotypes and did not develop over the course of the series; development seemed to have been limited to Usa and Ritsu primarily.


In terms of art, it took a middle-path kind of approach: the art style was fairly typical of moe, exaggerating neither cutesy features or more stylised anime styles, nor going into the realm of realistic and harder features. To highlight comedy and reactions, of course, it frequently resorted to other styles that meshed quite well. Animation was generally smooth and transparent. However, my one gripe with the art is the colouring and shading: with the saturated colours and particular style of shading, I felt like everything was too "shiny" in appearance, especially in contrast to the last series I watched, _Isshuukan Friends_.


The soundtrack was neither exceptional nor poor. It simply fit well into the genre, with music ranging from thoughtful or romantic solo piano works to more peppy, "daily life"/"RPG shop" style music.


All in all, I wouldn't go out of my way to praise this series, but for something light and amusing, with a sweet early romantic plot that's perhaps a cut above the norm, I wouldn't recommend against it. Just don't expect any literary award-winning material here.

Okay, Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou, let me just say, this was one of the few anime that I've completed within 2-3 days. It may not make my favorites but I did like it very much.
Let's start with the story. As this is a slice of life the story could be summed up as the daily lives of those who live in Kawai Complex. The stories usually only encompass one episode but are highly entertaining and funny.
As for the art.....Jesus Christ it's beautiful. This anime is a feast for the eyes. Some of the outfits that the characters wear are just gorgeous. At certain moments, whatit does with lighting and coloring is just so pretty! It also has its characters go into chibi forms to better help with comedic moments.


The Sound is....kinda good but not really impressive. For this aspect I primarily look at the openings and endings but it wasn't anything mind blowing. The song for the opening I kinda liked but how the visuals were set up didn't really impress me. The ending encapsulates the lives of the characters pretty well so that gives it more points in my book. All in all I preferred the ending theme to the opening one. As for background music, nothing really caught my attention.


The characters in this show were quirky and very funny. Many jokes were repeated but don't  I feel annoyed about it. I found the characters quite likeable and though they didn't contain the depths of the ocean within them, they had enough personality not to be boring after awhile. 


As I said earlier, I enjoyed this series a lot and would watch it again.

This is a slice of life series, you know – the type of anime that makes you feel super good, cuddly and fuzzy inside. Let’s start with the plot, which isn’t ground breaking to be honest, rather it indulges you in the typical unrequited romance that makes our small little hearts swell and churn when we want to smack the main character for being so BAKA! Usa-Kun, please just move on before my heart breaks! Usa-kun and Kawai-senpai are the main characters of this gorgeously done anime. Truly, the animation is stunning and the backgrounds don’t seem to be recycled; it truly seems like thestudio put a lot of love into this anime. The characters are very good-looking and those that aren’t intended to be, have a quirky and colorful personality to make up for it. And for me, that was what made this anime so great! The unique and peculiar personalities of the characters, their flaws and how their humor made the relentlessness of our main character bearable. If you are anything like me, and hate waiting for the “Big Ones” aka Naruto, One Piece & Dragon Ball Super, to get their ISH together and just come on already, then this anime is for you! It’s a 12-episode anime and you probably can bang it out in 1-2 days.

Pros:
 + Good animation with excellent use of vivid color
 + An enjoyable enough story
 + Accurate representation of what it is like to be an introvert
 + Anything that promotes a heroine who is a bookworm is a plus
 + Has supporting cast members who are adults
Cons:
 - The cast is under-developed and generic.  It is hard to care for anyone outside the proagonist and his love interest
 - If anyone in the cast, aside from the 2 main characters, experiences growth it is not apparent in the next episode
 - The love interest story is never fully resolved though a conclusion issomewhat implied\n
 - There are anime that handle romantic comedy, slice of life, and the "group of different people forced to live together" aspect much better\n
 - This anime suffers from the trope of embarrased teenagers not being honest with themselves, or others, about their feelings.  If you do not like being tantilized you will get frustrated\n\n
Review Summary: Run of the mill anime that, while having good animation and an interesting representation of how introverts think, runs amok in trying to execute character development.  Unfortunately this anime is average through and through.  If you want a romantic comedy set in a boarding house watch The Pet Girl of Sakurasou.\n\n
You may like this if:  You enjoy romantic comedies involving teenagers\n\n
Take it or leave it

An anime that grabs you by the arm every episode and says: "I hope you've come prepared for this wild ride!"
Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou is a romance anime which wraps you in its web of enjoyment and doesn't let go, making it the masterpiece that it is!
Within the first 10 minutes of the very first episode, it was easy to tell what the plot of the story was and if you carried on watching even after the first 10 minutes then it goes to show how great your reward was!
Usa, being our main character, wants an ordinary high school life, with a "decent" girlfriend. Bynow you probably thought this: "Hmph, another typical romance anime, MC wants a girlfriend...blah blah blah..." Boy, I can't tell you how wrong you were if you thought that! Though you'd be right in saying that SOME romance anime does tend to hover around the fact that the MC wants a girlfriend, I can't blame you for thinking that but what you must keep in mind is that Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou continuously provides you with what most romance animes couldn't: The sense of involvement.



By the end of the very first episode, you feel as though you'd do anything to live in the Kawai Complex with these strange, yet unique, characters. Usa already made his goal very clear in the first episode, and it is nearly impossible to not fall in love with this girl that Usa likes so much.


Ritsu, the girl of Usa's dreams, is by far the best female MC I have gotten the privilege to see in anime. Her behavior when she's around the little Kawai Complex group makes you wonder whether this anime can get any better than it already is. Also her hobby to read contrasts so well with Usa's general behavior in the anime, he's quite a noticeable guy whereas Ritsu is invisible, making this anime such a great watch. As for the other characters', they really do make the anime more enjoyable in the sense that they add sweetness to this very lighthearted anime. Their comedic moments are just hilarious and really brightens up your day!


I adore how this anime absolutely nails to combine its romantic moments and comedic moments together! Unlike most romance anime, Bokira wa Minna Kawaisou takes a different twist on the genre. It's an anime which you can count on to NOT provide you with tons of mishaps or misunderstandings.


We can all learn from Usa's determination to get Ritsu, his adored Senpai, to notice him. If there's someone that we truly care about then there are nothing stopping you from confessing/showing your gratitude and love towards them. 


Reasons why I like the anime:

-It is the VERY FIRST anime I have seen, and I've seen many anime's, where the characters' doesn't have bizarre hair colors!

-The chemistry between each character is so strong that you'd be mad to not want to live with them in the Kawai Complex.

-Ritsu is so adorable!! I became envious of Usa! :(

-I was moved by Usa's love towards his Senpai, Ritsu.

-Shiro, Usa's masochistic roommate, made me laugh every episode.

-The landlady of the Kawai Complex made me realize how kind and accepting some people are if you open up to them.

-I felt as though I was a part of the Kawai Complex group, I considered them as family.



Reasons why I did NOT like the anime:

-I wouldn't consider this as a spoiler but we were, in a way, left on a cliffhanger on the last episode. I would be over the moon if a second season came out but I wouldn't know!



As for things like sound, character, art and story, I'd say that each and every aspect was done to an exceptional effort. The story keeps you engaged and makes you curious to what the next episode has ready for you. The sound is amazing, really puts your mind at ease. The characters' are so caring towards each other (that's a lie, Usa doesn't like most of them but in a friendly way, making Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou the definition of a 'perfect romance anime'



Overall, I'd say that this anime really set the bar up VERY high. 


I'd give it an 20/10. A must watch! Thanks for reading! =)

Genaro's anime review #1: Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou
Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou is directed by Shingeyuki Miya and the 28th TV series produced by studio Brain's Base.
Story - 5.5
The story has the lowest point of the show, it's a slife of life comedy romance show so what did you expect? The story is about your average highschool boy, his junior high school life was a disaster because he always encounters weird people so he tries to spend his high school life in peace and wanted to have a intellectual and refined girlfriend. Until he find himself moving to Kawai Complex that's full of weird people w/ccompletely ruined everthing.


Art - 8

The art is very colorful and really cute,but sometimes the screen is just a character and some random color in the background and I'm not really a fan of art so I have nothing else to say.


Sound - 8

The OP is really good, very worth watching every episode. And the ED is really cute, I have no idea what the lyrics is but I really love it and I can see myself listening to it everytime.


Characters - 8

The characters is very well made and very unforgettable. We have Usa w/c I always red as USA also known as Oddball Handler cause for some unexplained reason he always got stuck w/ weird people. Ricchan who is Usa's love interest that loves books, she seriously love reading books that she didn't care if someone's going to rape her. Sumiko the manager of Kawai Complex who is old enough to shrink. Mayumi who has a big boobs and bad luck w/ men. Shiro, Usa's masochist roomate that gets turned on in almost everthing. And Sayaka... who is really cute and loves to tease Usa and Ricchan a lot. 


Enjoyment - 9.5

I really enjoyed this show, there's just the time when it's so slow and that is when Ricchan is on screen talking and kinda annoys me. I also didn't like when USA and Ricchan is alone talking about books, I just can't relate. If someone finished watching this and says he/she didnt enjoy it, they was probably lying. Because I can't imagine someone watching this and don't laugh out loud.


Overall - 7.8

I gived Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou a 7.8 and I give thanks for it is only a 12 episode show, I will be bored otherwise. Oh, I'm still curious what happened w/ Hayashi and that spirit guy.


The End and Thank you for reading.

Before I write this review I would like to state that this is my opinion you may disagree or agree at your own will.
Review:
I used to only watch action, adventure, and just more darker anime usually but when a friend suggested that I watch Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou I was really confused because she knew I didn't watch this kinda of anime. This anime opened me too a whole new genre of anime that I could enjoy and it even opened me to try to watch other genres. Bokure wa Minna Kawaisou is one of my favorite anime and it's a romance anime at that.This anime is a perfect blend of many things. The intro isn't the best but still suits the anime fine. Character wise they let you grow attached to the MC by making you feel for him and actually kinda care about what he does. The love interest in the anime is one of those strong, book reading, silent type of girls who you will adore. The side characters are hilarious and you actually care to get to know them and want to see them on screen. The only problem with this anime is some of it's conflict. Without conflict nothing can progress throughout anything. Conflict arises and that's what starts every anime, book, movie you name it. The conflict itself isn't the problem it's how the characters handle it. It's one of those many things I hate in anime where the characters have a problem but decided to do the most difficult way possible to solve the problem. Where something that could be cleared up in 2 episodes takes 4 which I'm not a big fan of because if you're only gonna be a 12 episode season make the most of it. All in all Bokure wa Minna Kawaisou is one of my top anime I have ever watched.

This is my first review, but this anime absolutely clicked with me so I really want to write about it. Also, it should be noted that there are only 10 episodes out of (I think) 13 out so far, so the "climax" and most dramatic parts are still to be shown.
Anyway, it is safe for me to say that this is my favorite anime this season and depending on the ending may be up there as one of my favorite anime in general as well. This is because of multiple elements that make up the refreshing and, in my opinion, unique experience of watching thisseries. 


Story [8/10]:

The best thing that I like about the story is that there is no horsing around with who the male protagonist, Usa, likes. It is clear from episode one that he is heads-over-heels for shy, bookworm, and possibly loner, Ritsu. This makes it easier for the audience to form an emotional connection with their growing relationship as there is no wondering "Oh, is he gonna start liking this girl? Oh, what about this transfer student, is he gonna like her now? Who will he end up with?". The audience pretty much knows that they will end up together but since Ritsu is pretty anti-social it's all about how Usa goes about getting closer to her. Having all the characters live in the same complex makes for some hilarious and smart situations. Overall, for 13 episodes only, the series is refreshingly slow-paced and lighthearted and very relatable.


Art [9/10]:

As an artist myself, I very much enjoy the art of this anime. Though nothing "revolutionary", the use of colors and lighting is absolutely gorgeous and fits the mood of the anime so well. If you pay attention you'll notice that much of the anime takes place when the sun is setting or rising and this gives plenty of opportunity for the anime to show off it's beautiful spectrum of colors. It's safe to say that there are many scenes where you can see the whole spectrum of the rainbow and values from very dark to very bright. The show would just not be the same without the art style.


Sound [8/10]:

The opening and ending songs could be better, but I have gotten attached to them as I have watched the current episodes multiple times each and never skip them. Although, where the sound truly shines are the moments between Usa and Ritsu. I still remember the piano medley playing when Usa and Ritsu first meet eachother and how it suited the atmosphere so well. Overall, the music score never gets boring and knows just how to set the mood of any scene especially romantic ones.


Character [10/10]:

The characters have to be the best part about this anime. There are six main characters who live in the same complex and all of them are of different ages. It is only Ritsu and Usa who are close to the same age and that also reinforces their "fated" love because the older tenants are constantly either helping make or break their relationship. The interactions between characters in this anime are some of the most down-to-earth and realistic I've seen in a series so far. There is nothing outlandish like constant pantyshots or somehow tripping and grabbing a breast or even a bathtub scene (so far, atleast). Each of the situations and conversations the characters have gotten into are something that could easily take place in real life and that makes it all the more relatable to the viewer. I especially hate the "frenemy" dynamics of Mayumi and Sayaka. As girls who are insecure in their own ways they are really catty to eachother and I know many girls in real life who are like that. 


Enjoyment [10/10]:

I took a break from anime and even when I got back into it last month I haven't encountered one that made me want to rewatch it as soon as I finished it, or caught up to the most recent episode. This is the one that did it for me. I have seen the current episodes at least three times each and it maybe takes me 40 minutes to watch a single one because I'm constantly replaying parts. I don't know what the "secret ingredient" is or why I enjoy Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou so much but there is just something special about it. If you read this far you would have seen the word "relatable" many times by now and that's because this anime is just that, at least to me. I'm a hopeless romantic who's first love and romance was very much less sweet and innocent as Ritsu and Usa's so I guess the combined "romanticized love" and relatability of the situations and conversations of the series makes it a winner to me.


Overall [10/10]:

I feel like I really buttered this anime up and at the same time might lack experience to say it's the bomb.com but I feel how I feel about it right now and that's what's important. Toradora! is my favorite anime of all time and what I consider a masterpiece of rom-com. Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou is no Toradora!, I have not shed a tear yet, or gotten angry or too anxious. But it is that in itself that makes this anime special. It's a true "slice-of-life". No cliche's, no situations that would never happen, but all nostalgia of a time when relationships were so innocent and friendships didn't hurt.


Great anime.

Imagine you're starting a new high school life with a new city and new home. You did not like that home at first, but you find a girl you had a crush on and decided to stay.
Let's take a look at "Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou" main two charecters:
- Usa "Kazunari Usa", a high school student resides at Kawai Complex, a resident full of weird people. The main reason he chooses to stay at the complex is for the girl he liked on first sight, Ritsu Kawai, a senior of his and a resident at the same complex.
- Kawai "Ritsu Kawai", a shy girl who hasa great passion on reading books and loves to share that passion.\n\n
The story is about Usa and Kawai, how the friendship between them is built up, what events and circumstances that happen to bond these two and make them know more of each other.. well, at least one of them is : )\n\n
The story has some similarities to "Honey and Clover" and to "Sakurasou", so if you enjoyed these two you might enjoy watching "Kawaisou" as well.

Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou is an okay romantic, slice of life comedy. Though it follows the usual plot progression. Main character is a nice guy that gets thrown into a new life style where he meets the stories side characters. Side characters all follow some sort of character trope and have no real character development. The story really only follows the group at the apartment complex and does not really delve deeper into his school life.
The art really had me to watch the whole show. I really liked the art, very bright colors and well drawn characters. I especially liked the heroine and how theycolored eyes, very sparkly. I do not really know how to express how the art is just watch one episode and you will see. \n
 Main character is a nice guy to a fault, just the usual main character seen in any other romance anime. The heroine is the shy, lonely, library girl trope which usually does not get the heroine spot so it was interesting to see how they progressed the plot with her and the main character. At some times it is very hard to see the two together and I personally thought that the MC acted creepy sometimes towards the heroine but not so much so that it turned me off to the show. Just some teenage inexperience and awkwardness. Overall a good representation of teenagers.

7/10
Overall the show succeeded in presenting an interesting and funny depiction on the typical romance format, with it focusing more so on the humor than the actual romance between the two leads. Though it should be said the romance established within the story is still endearing and entertaining to watch unfold slowly over the course of its 12 episodes. My main issue arises from the wasted  potential on some of the characters, as unfortunately most of the supporting cast are completely two dimensional even after events that would influence their outlook or personality, making them feel unmemorable. This is similar to the setting itself,as by the around the 4th episode it begins to fade into the background entirely and ends up being another generic location.\n

Bokura wa minna is a wonderful slice of life with a romantic touch. It's nice how the story and animation is carried out, the relationship of each of the characters and the comic situations in a natural way. With beautiful teachings about life. 
They present us with completely opposite characters that are able to unfold in a wonderful way throughout history and develop a unique romance between the protagonist and his beloved and surprisingly doesn't become repetitive.
A comedy that doesn't disappoint you and doesn't get boring at any time.
The opening and ending are pleasant in the visual and sound. 
Good design of characters.

An anime adaptation of a not-so-big big but popular enough series of the same name. You might be thinking "A friend of mine told me this was great but then I read a plot synopsis and saw the first bit of the first episode and sort of don't get it." Well this is exactly what nobody has said because most people lose interest after reading the "unoriginal" plot synopsis and don't actually give it a go.
So what is "Bokura wa minna Kawaisou"? Well it's about a young Usa who wants to live a simple life, but the people around him just don't let that happen,from his fellow Kawai Sou residents to his own parents, everyone loves to be...... "unique". Now, some people say this anime is bland, however from where I sit, I can't understand where that statement comes in. The colour palette makes every bit of scenery look like art and the animation is very well done. Despite very little action if not almost no action at all happening throughout the series, the animators always find a way to make as many things happen on screen as possible. if it's not in the foreground, it'll be in the background, if it's not in the background, it'll be in the corner. It feeds the viewer a consistent stream of joy if you enjoy it's humour.


Speaking of it's humour! It's a little unique in which the characters are somewhat aware of their own media. However this is not the same as Seitokai no Ichizon or Joshiraku where the characters directly state that they're in an anime, but more so the characters for example may for some reason be able to hear the other character's thoughts or may directly reference the onomatopoeic words used often in japanese manga which appear on screen. However you never once lose the immersion as this feels almost like the best way to tell the story in this show. I wish I could describe it better, but the humour in this show somehow has both variety and consistency, which makes it unique in it's own way.


So what do I like most about this show? Well because I can rewatch it several times and still get a good laugh out of it, the voice actors and animators seem to have put in 100% effort on all fronts, the comedy is well timed, there's just enough fan service for it not to be in the way but still enjoyable and the characters, while sound like stereotypes, have several layers to their personalities which can be explored by each and every character interaction. But most of all, the adults look, feel and behave like adults, while the kids all look, feel and behave like kids, which is something anime often gets wrong.


So what do I recommend for this show? Watch it, and if you don't like it, then fair enough, but I think you'll like it.

It really is an underrated show.

These days we'll find plenty of comedic, slice of life shows following a boy during his journey known as high school. However, often we find that the reality of the "high school" is in fact an elementary school filled with overly-moe girls and other chuunibyou-obsessed archetypes. Well, this show bucks that trend by presenting a cast that actually acts relatively of age, and for once truly presents some seinin-level comedy without having to resort to super powers or cat ears. The best description I can think of is a Sakurasou setting (and arguably heroine) with the behavioral maturity of Golden Time. The show isn't goingto win any awards for its plot progression but the interactions are great, and proves that there is still life after moe. All studios should take note, this is a slice of life done right.


Animation:

The show is surprisingly well drawn for the genre. Expect nicely-saturated coloring, crisp lines, excellent shading and detail. The show strikes a nice balance between serious and comedic moments, it does come across as bit more of the latter with hiragana popups and colorful, flat backgrounds to emphasize moments. The character design is very good with distinct characters and good facial animations. I'm usually not a fan of the kuudere, bookworm type but, unlike certain other shows, there was enough dere in Ritsu's behaviors and facial expressions to win me over.


This show doesn't focus on action so aside from some comedic references I wouldn't expect much. The show has a bit of light ecchi, much of it is implied through speech sort of like Seitokai Yakuindomo, aside from Shirosaki's masochism. Expect some suggesting scenes and a lot of jokes based on relationships, body part sizes, experience levels, etc.


Sound:

The show opens with a light and refreshing-sounding OP and closes with a more playful tune sung by the heroines. The show has a relatively active BGM and sound effects track. Much of the BGM is calming though so it may be a bit sleep inducing if watched too late.


Much of the show's plot and comedy are dialogue-driven so expect the VA's to play a big role in the show. They deliver brilliantly with talents including Kana Hanazawa, Rina Satou, and Hisako Kanemoto. Kanahana masterfully navigates Ritsu's kuudere personality while Rina Satou keeps things lively with the loud and bolsterous Mayumi. I haven't heard much of late from Hisako Kanemoto but she delivers marvelously here.


Story:

Usa-kun has had to manage interesting personalities around him all his life, and now all he wants is a peaceful and normal high school life. Thus, he manages to convince his parents to send him to a boarding house where he can finally live on his own. To his immediate dismay, he finds that he actually has a roommate across a partition, and even worse he seems to be a masochistic bum. Moments later, while running out, he discovers that his sempai and crush, Ritsu, also lives at the Kawai Complex. The show follows Usa's daily routine as he interacts with the distinct residents at the complex and attempts fruitlessly to win Ritsu's heart.


The show is full of up and down moments like the ones in the past paragraph. It soon becomes clear that Usa's daily life is anything but routine as he ends up working a part-time job and dealing with various shenanigans from his housemates. The show is mostly episodic with a slight build up of tension towards the end, though there's not much of a conclusion. The comedy feels refreshing with a good variety of jokes ranging from cultural norms to those of a more sexual nature. What I particularly enjoyed was how a lot of these jokes tied into Usa's relationship with Ritsu and how he always ended up at the wrong place at the wrong time to only win her ire.


If you're looking for a light show with a good dose of comedy, and don't need a very focused plot, this is a good watch. However, be aware that the romance is only fleeting, there's just enough progress to keep your hope alive but nothing comes of it.


Character:

Despite the great animation, I think this is where this show shines the most. The characters in this show feel like they have an air of maturity that is sorely lacking elsewhere in the anime realm. Yes, they do behave immature from time to time, especially when under a few drinks, but overall the tonality and subjects are a few years beyond your typical moe show. All the characters have decent backgrounds and very strong characterization. Though Sayaka's makeup witchcraft is a bit scary, most of the characters are also pretty relatable, especially Usa with his development with Ritsu. Despite being a bit on the slow side, the development does make some progress, and the show does a great job of milking it for maximum value.


Value:

Overall, this was a very enjoyable show. It isn't the type of show that you absolutely must watch in one sitting but the interactions alone are entertaining enough to keep you going. If you're looking for some good'ol slice of life before the days of K-on but with up to date animation styling, definitely give this a try.
